question: Question_02
sols:
To find the limits of the integral that calculates the area, we need to
find the intersection points of the two functions $f$ and $g$ and so we
set the functions equal.

\begin{align*}f(x)\ = g(x)\end{align*}

That means

\begin{align*}x^3-4x=-x^2+2x\end{align*}

and leads to

\begin{align*}x(x+3)(x-2)=0\end{align*}

So, we find that the functions intersect three times at
$x=-3,\ x=0,\ x=2$. However, we have a constraint that $x\geq{0}$ and so
we will only be concerned with the interval {[}0,2{]}. We need to
integrate the function $f-g$ or $g-f$ (depending on which is the upper
and which is the lower curve).

Now we check which function is the upper function. One way to do this is
to simply plug in any point in the interval and compare the function
values. On {[}0,2{]} we choose \emph{x = 1} and get \emph{f(1) = -3},
\emph{g(1)=1}. Hence \emph{g \textgreater{} f} on {[}0,2{]}.

Therefore, the area \emph{A} is given by

\begin{align*}A = \int_{0}^2(g(x)-f(x))dx.\end{align*}

\begin{align*}\ A &= \int_{0}^2(g(x)-f(x))dx\\
 &= \int_0^2(-x^2+2x-x^3+4x)dx\\
 &= \left[-\frac{x^3}{3}+6\frac{x^2}{2}-\frac{x^4}{4}\right]_0^2\\
 &= -\frac{2^3}{3}+6\frac{2^2}{2}-\frac{2^4}{4} - 0\\
 &= \frac{16}3\end{align*}

Therefore the area of A is 16/3.
